segments.text: to finish on part of that was, if you're an American unit, you only saw the Vietnamese in battle, near battles, getting ready for battle, just after a battle.
You're going through an area.
Yes, there was the, I think, troop-wise, particularly, other than a few gestures caught on, a few words for certain things, a barrier.
The big surprise was how many Vietnamese spoke English.
The children would speak English, you know, called GI slang English.
The advisors would stay in an area long enough, and a lot of them were second, third tour people, who had been there, were back, that you were more at home.
In fact, we had some advisors who everybody had to be fluent in French because they worked with an artillery unit, and the Vietnamese artillery was done in French.
So you had second and third languages you could converse in in a lot of cases.
A lot of our operators spoke other languages that the Vietnamese would speak, and you had one or two in common.
And you weren't this...
Plus, after you stayed in the area, you could go into the markets.
You could go places.
You didn't have the feeling.
You may have still been isolated.
Don't make that mistake.
But you didn't have this feeling of, I'm totally alone in this town.
If something happens, nobody's going to help me.
After you lived there a while, you felt when it was.
And the Vietnamese would say, no operation today.
We stay in the compound.
You knew the commons were doing something.
They didn't tell you.
If you want to go on downtown, go ahead.
Remember, it's your risk.
And you developed a, I would say, a more personal relationship.
You saw the people in different lights.
You saw them out plowing the fields and some of the jobs I went through.
You went out and you worked with the rural development programs and things.
You worked with them, so you were out there.
And it wasn't this, you didn't drive by at 50 miles an hour in a truck and look out and see Vietnam.
Dismount from the helicopter and go into battle.
That was the difference.
I didn't live in a wire compound.
I was in wire.
But I was in a Vietnamese compound with Vietnamese.
We had our own cooks.
We ate mostly their food.
We ate ours.
Advisors were not supplied with food.
You acquired your food on the market.
So...
This gave you contact.
If you wanted to eat your breakfast or whatever the hell you ate, remember don't sit at the same table and vary your time, otherwise you'll be a stat.
You'll just come up with statistics.

If you get dumb and you go to breakfast every morning at 8 o'clock, 8 o'clock, 8 o'clock, 8 o'clock, 8 o'clock, somebody's gonna catch on and you go to breakfast every morning at 8 o'clock, shoot the suits down at 8 o'clock.
So you had to do that kind of a thing, but...
Uh, you weren't this, uh... You were constantly under surveillance.
You were always under surveillance.
You just got used to just...
There's a war on, everybody's got their spies, both sides did.
You tried to vary your routine enough that nobody would nail you.
Don't be dumb.
Uh, don't go to town by yourself.
Don't go without a weapon.
Don't go without loading it.
Uh, but I worked in an area that you could drive...

between towns unarmed was that pacified normally it could also you could drive into a thousand men force crossing that area so it's just which card did the deck turn up did you flip a joker or an ace you flip the ace nothing's wrong you flip the joker we'll see about it how did you cope with this with the stress that was inherent in especially i guess with the phoenix
You know what's funny, and you asked that at Air Force, if there's a battle on, you don't feel it.
Probably the biggest stress was always trying to please the commander, and after a while, you kind of got calloused.
I did, and some others I know worked around there did.
We didn't care.
Now, you got long-term, I guess, look at it and be fair, we got long-term stress from the war.
Nobody knew about it then.
I mean, naive enough, young enough to...
You lived over it, and that's all it counted.
You know, I got back with ten toes and fingers.
Did it bother you?
No.

Well, you know, day to day in the advisory program, the biggest stress, I guess, would have been in the U.S. Army units where you didn't know if the phone was going to ring at 3 a.m. or 6 a.m. Load up, Lieutenant, it's time to go somewhere.
Where is where?
Get on the chopper.
We'll brief you.
We'll brief you for 20 minutes.
The order of battle people are here.
The interrogators are going.
Here's your briefing.
Here's a briefing from the
electronic warfare groups, radio research, ASA.
You went.
When you were going to battle, there wasn't time to worry about it.
After it was over, most of the guys came back and just got them a good nose full of drinking.
It was go out, shoot up the woods or get shot up, come in and drink.
It was a tension breaker.
In true life, you want to go swim in the ocean with the sharks, you couldn't.
I don't think, in saying, you know, how do you handle stress, I don't think we looked at it that way.
It was just a job that had bullets involved.
I think a lot of it was not looking at it, but there wasn't any program around, would you like to talk about how you feel?
Are you kidding?
You talk about how you feel and say it the wrong way, you'll, mm, let's watch him.
So everybody caught on, just don't say anything.
If you weren't looking at the end of a bottle, that was your business.
I'd be ready to go at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning or whenever.
I don't think the Army had a plan for that.
It was just something that wasn't looked at.
At least I never thought about it.
I'm not aware of ever sitting down and saying, hey, let's have a talk about stress.

I think after operations that went wrong or some of your friends got killed or wounded, I think you felt emotional ups and downs, but I never did really, if you want to sound silly, associate that with stress.
I'd sure like to go out there next time and kick them
be with the crew it goes, you know, but I mean that was the thing there.
What did you think of the military leadership during your days in Vietnam?
You know, when you ask what do you think of leadership, and I guess one of the things working at the staff where you have a two-star general, and then on a team where there's a colonel,
I think the leaders, and this is, of course, looking in total retrospect, I think the leaders sat in their offices too much.
It's a joke that goes and went in Vietnam.
What other war could you fight in if you were a commander from a helicopter at 5,000 feet?
You fly home and the troops and the intelligence crew walks back.
I'm not saying they're incompetent.
I don't think that was the case, but I think something looking backward, and it'll be true in the next war the same as this one.
You always fight the last war you fought the best.
You fight it again.
We fought the World War II model in Vietnam with a modification from Korea.
You know, we talk about how mobile are we.
Well, we'll give you a helicopter.
It can haul you anywhere.
We put you on the ground.
Let's see you walk with 125 pounds.
We can get you from point A to B, the big spot.
It was moving you on the ground that 10 clicks was tough.
The leadership probably, in truth, ranged from very good to bad.
We had an Americal Division.
One of our assistant deputy commanders relieved for failing to provide his troops enough water.
I'm not sure what I think of.
Fill your canteen this morning and carry two of them because you may not have any more water until the shooting stops.
It's what a war is about.
I think the leadership probably got lied to also, which affects how I see it.
I've read that a lot of the
The leaders didn't want to, they wouldn't report bad.
Oh, no, no, no.
You don't, no, no, no, no.
Don't do that.
You reported, at least in some cases, what you knew the boss wanted to hear.
We developed the body count game as an example of what you had to do.
If your promotion depended on how many men you killed, not how good a leader were you,
You got what they term the ratio.
You have to get your ratio of kills up, Lieutenant.
It's sort of like working on an assembly line, turning out sets.
You're doing a fine job, but we don't need two sets a day from you.
We need two every 10 minutes.
You've assembled them perfectly.
There's nothing wrong with them.
Now get the numbers up.
Instead of saying, were you good leaders or bad leaders?
Were you lucky or unlucky?
It became, how many of them compared to you as a fraction did you kill?
I'm not always sure the guys higher up knew what happened out there.
It's been said that they followed the strategy of attrition, that that was the only strategy.
Oh, well, it was one of them.
And one of the reasons it was one of them was, how do you measure success in killing an enemy army?
Count the bodies.
It's sort of like, you see, unfortunately it worked out was,
They had an endless supply of people, and we did too.
It's like going in a football game.
You play with a sprained ankle, a jammed thumb.
Now you've got your second thumb sprained.
You've twisted your knee.
How much pain do you play with?
The problem of counting bodies was if it had been finite limits on each side that was going to get there, it's okay.
But by the way, how do you decide when you've got a stack of dead ends?
The soldiers are not sure they are.
You don't kill civilians.
Count them.
One, two.
How many guns?
Well, gosh, a couple.
Do you have to have, and we even developed a rule in some areas you had to put your foot on the chest of the dead man.
Step on him if you want to call it that.
Count him.
Because people lied.
Sir, I think we got about, and you fill in the blank.
Pick a good number.

You see, you had just got chewed last week for not having enough, so this weekend a firefight away from everybody else, you still didn't get enough, but Sarge, there ain't nobody ever going to know but us.
Send them 10.
The numbers were suspect.
Who got counted?
You counted everything that was out there.
If it was dead.
If it's dead, count it.
Hold on.
There's also been a lot of talk about careerism with officers.
Well, I think ticket punching was prevalent.
If you wanted to stay, you better look like a duck, quack like a duck, walk like a duck.
If you didn't, you weren't going to be a duck.
And there's an elite inside the Army.
An army within an army, if you want to call it that.
And they always will be in any bureaucracy, and that's what an army is.
Any bureaucracy you have has the elite inside of it.
Some group in charge whose definition of standards are the rules we all work by.
It may help you.
It may hurt you.
In this instance, you were out of touch.
I think the group inside was out of touch.
But it's the old game of how do you reform something that size?
A well-intentioned reform turns into disaster when you implement it.
And one of the problems was the criteria we judged lieutenants on.
By the way, anybody who got a rating in the Army didn't take in personality conflicts.
It didn't allow for other things that may have affected scores.
And it became a game.
If you wanted to stay in, you had to do certain things at certain points in your career.
You had to.
You had to command at certain times.
If you didn't, you would be a staff officer forever.
Don't expect to rise to general.
You had to find the firefight to get yourself well decorated.
Because that was a ticket punch to show everybody above you, those below didn't count.
Don't worry about them.
It's all the ones above who look back and say, hey, look at this one.
He walks on water.
I forgot to tell them it was January 1st in Wisconsin, but that's okay.
He's got the required I was there.
Click.
You had to know how the team played the game.
Don't be a maverick.
Don't rock the boat.
Boat rocking could be discouraged.
It could prove hazardous to your health.
But I think there's a trade-off out there.
If you did the best job you could, then you took the lick however it came down.
If it was good, fine.
If it was bad, so what?
And to say something of all the medals and all the money and all the decorations you can put on a soldier,
If he's satisfied with himself and what he did, there's nothing you can put on him.
And if he's not, I don't care what you hang out there.
You can't make him what he's not.
And an old man in World War I remarked, been to Vietnam and other places, said, 40 cents and all your medals will get you a cup of coffee in a cheap restaurant.
It's still true.
They're one sign of it.
And some guys get them and shouldn't have them.
Some don't.
Some do.
It's potluck dinner.
It's what did your boss think of what you were doing.
Suppose your ratio was a little low, lieutenants.
Your boss don't decorate you.
Heck no.
So get your ratio higher than the other three lieutenants.
And now you see, suddenly, I knew it.
I knew it all along.
See, I told you.
If you just do what I said, see, you caught on.
He didn't catch on and learn how to play the game.
What's the boss looking for?
Do I want shine shoes, good haircuts?
I don't want you producing.
It's quite judgment scale.
We use a lot of shine boots and haircuts.
Someone said, don't have the guy in front of you stop too soon because you could get hurt in a traffic jam.
But there was a lot of it, sure.
I think all armies work on it.
If you look like one, you act like one, you associate with one, maybe you become one.
I don't know.
I'll leave it at that.
I think that's what it might be.
For the first time ever, fragging became a significant statistic in Vietnam.
We had, where I was, no problem.
I will say I was in places where in official capacity it had happened.
But I was not there for any of it.
We had a Marine unit near our compound in July that somebody tried to get their first sergeant.
They didn't get him.
He took the whole company outside in their shorts, and he found all the hidden grenades.
But we simply didn't have the problem.
Most of ours, where I was in the problem, were stupid accidents that we investigated.
Dumbness.
People blowing fingers off with cleaning rods and rifles before checking to see if they were moved around from the chamber.
But we didn't have, where I was and wasn't aware of it being an incident until I came back, or near that time, I mean, yeah.
It was brought to our attention later, they didn't, hey.
But no contact with it.
So did you, back on to the kill ratio strategy of attrition as a measure of success, do you think that's an important statistic?
I mean, what effect do you think it had on the troops?
I mean, what effect, obviously, is it people falling?
Everybody lied.
Everybody lied.
I shouldn't say it in quotes.
We'll put it in quotes.
Everybody that everybody ever heard about lied, but none of them ever did it themselves.
Maybe the way to say that.
Never did it myself, but all my friends lied.
I probably just got an answer there.
But you see, it's something I can measure.
What do you think would have been a more appropriate measure?
That's the hard part.
Counting bodies was the easy part.
If there's anything to count, well, here's one and there's one.
We didn't try to judge the battles.
Were they big units?
Were you outgunned?
Were you overwhelmed?
How did you do in a specific circumstance?
That wasn't.
That would have taken more judgment.
And you don't want subjective calls.

You want something you can measure that I can absolutely walk out, Lieutenant, point my finger in your face as a commanding general and say, you, Lieutenant, are the finest lieutenant I've got in this division.
I wish all my lieutenants were like you.
It was easy that way.
The hard ones to do is what happened if your unit never went in combat?
And the one time it did, you lost three guys and bagged nobody.
You had a terrible kill ratio.
You lost three guys and didn't get anybody.
Your whole career could have been finished on that.
The one contact you had.
You got lucky.
You walked out there.
The artillery tube was laid on the spot you were on.
Here they came, and you killed 1,100 of them.
Man, I wish every platoon leader.
It's the examples.
It's how we use the example of the kill ratio, I think, was the bad part.
I'm not sure measuring it or not measuring is good or bad in itself.
I think you need to kind of keep up with it.
But we made it the all or nothing.
You had to be the best every time you went out.
You had to walk on water no matter what the temperature was.
OK.
What was your opinion of the enemy?
Professional.
Doing the job.
And I'm basically talking about the North Vietnamese Army.
At least compared in a way to us, and I'm using quote marks, highly motivated, believed in a cause versus I'm there for my year in some cases.
A lot of others, they were just sent there as punishment.
You acted bad in North Vietnam, your father didn't do what we want, so we shipped the kids south as punishment.
It varied.
Their officer corps and their staffs were probably as good as ours.
When you get out into this game, what do you think of the gorilla you caught carrying a bag of rice?
He got taken out of the village at gunpoint.
And not having a gun, if I'd have been in his spot in that village, I'd have been carrying a bag of rice, impressed into the service.
Gunpoint draft.
Both armies used it.
South Vietnamese used it.
The VC, the NVA, if they needed a lot of equipment, move and walk in a village, take every male with them.
You carry the rockets, you carry the equipment.
As soon as they finished portering this heavy job, they'd turn you loose and send you home.
They didn't want to feed you either.
But the core of their army was pro.
And I think that's the mispicture we have.
We painted ourselves a picture of a stupid little guy in a conical hat
who can't do anything right.
And we were the only fools that bought the picture.
Self-deception.
And I would think that was the big, and I think the higher up it went, the bigger that picture got.
If you hadn't been there, the only thing you had that said Vietnam was what it was was reported across your desk.
You know, and if someone asked someone to describe the war in Vietnam, it's impossible.
Three corps with every terrain feature you want, every level of intensity of warfare, from guerrilla, from sniping, from mining, to stand up and slug it out with you in a set-piece battle.
And we were there for 20 years.
Tactics equipment evolved.
The war remained a constant, and we kept counting numbers.
There's no way to describe it.
It was never the same in your place, two days.
One day it's a perfectly peaceful village you've driven through a hundred times, and tomorrow you come in and everybody in the world is personally down there trying to get you.
That's what it feels like.
And, you know, the morale question we had, do you?
And I think both sides fought with a different set of handbooks.
We fought with one that held Americans to a different standard, at least on paper, than the other side employed.
I'm not sure, looking backward, that I would want it any other way.
At the same time, I think we need to be more realistic about why are we there to start with.
You know, one of the things that evolved out of a lot of guys, if you're going to fight a war, go to win and go stay home.
And I teach government and understand and recognize the difference between a declaration of war and an undeclared war.
However, for the people you send to carry out your foreign policy, I think it would help if you had a clear objective, and we never had a clear objective.
It was do this and do that and do the other.
It's been said in Vietnam, we didn't lose any of the battles.
We won all the battles and lost the war.
We lost battles.
We got surprised.
We got ambushed.
We got killed.
Compared to what we did to the other side, we killed thousands, if not millions.
And one of the questions was, if you want to look at Vietnam as an exercise in strangeness, we dropped more tonnage of bombs in Vietnam than we dropped in World War II.
But what did we bomb?
We bombed bridges.
We bombed things that we thought would disrupt something.
You bomb the wrong targets because their army didn't operate the way your army operated.
Everybody always assigns or ascribes to the other person your characteristics, your creature comforts, your habits.
What if it doesn't happen?
You know, one of the things we didn't do, we didn't break the dam above Hanoi and Haiphong and flood the country.
We didn't blow up the railway tunnel.
the Chinese had on the border region.
We didn't do a bunch of things, and I'm not sure, you know, what the consequence.
They didn't ask lieutenants, do you want to go do these things, lieutenant?
You do what you're told.
But there are a lot of things you wonder, why wasn't something different done?
Not that you had a plan.
Most of us didn't.
Hi, here I am.
What's going on?
Can I keep my backside attached to my front side?
What was your opinion of the South Vietnamese body forces, RFPS?
Well, the Arvins fought well when well led.
But you had to recognize what caused the Arvin problems was the commanders farmed them out as servants, hired labor, made them buy their own rations, stole from their own troops.
The soldiers themselves
We're no better or no worse than your own army and the other side.
It's what does leadership or lack of leadership do to your army?
I think that was the problem, was the corruptness.
Up the chain, not at the very bottom.
At the very bottom, I have nothing but respect for all of them.
And I fought with units that ran, and I fought with units that stood.
And it hangs on leadership.
You earn your pay, Lieutenant.
It's time to stand up.
Anybody...
And we tell the joke, anybody could manage a company as long as you got all the money and spare parts you need.
It's when you're out of money and out of parts, let's see how good a manager you are.
When it's not going right is when you should judge management, when it's tough.
And I think the call was, yeah, their army ran.
Called them a lot of things.
A lot of the troops did.
I think it was easier to call them that from an American viewpoint until you worked in the advisor program and really saw what happened.
Once you were internal to seeing part of it, then the picture changed why the guys ran.
You now got the answer to the question you never had as the American unit.
They didn't run because they wanted to.
They ran because they were out of supplies or out of ammunition, out of equipment.
There were units that didn't work right.
But the area I was in, we didn't have that problem with them.
They had problems with stealing petty stuff, chickens and things.
The Vietnamese solved that own problem in their own judicial system.
We didn't get into theirs.
You've already mentioned what you thought about the tour of duty.
And did you say that the military's gone back to the... We are going back to what's called cohorts, our fixed regimental size units, things maybe with different names.
But a group of people will enter, serve, work together, train together, fight together, be replaced together.
It's stability is what we're heading back to.
You think that policy had a... Can you really measure the effect?
Yeah, I think you can measure the effect.
I think you can look at Vietnam and the next war you fight and measure that effect.
I think you can look at World War II.
You see, both of these things have a trade-off.
If I send a unit, and I want to use a National Guard unit for an example, and this happened in Pennsylvania...
If you send a guard unit who was in the same town, trained together, and you kill them all on the same day, you've killed a town.
But they work together.
There's other way you send 160 guys, 167 guys on a plane, you dump them off in a unit.
There's 167 strangers standing there.
Who cares?
There are risks each way.
I think the biggest...
Gain is the stability.
And I think it far outweighs what happens to one town or one group of people who've worked together.
I think you perform better if everybody knows exactly what the other guy is going to do when the shove comes.
There's no question.
Old Smith's going to be out there hanging on because he's always hung on.
It's not what is Old Smith going to be doing.
American firepower, did we use it effectively in Vietnam?
Did we just...
Nah.
We bound the wrong things.
We had the fire powers misutilized.
We used indiscriminate shooting.
An example, we have a thing called H&I fire harassment and interdiction.
You pick out a grid, they call the intel types like myself, and said, you got anything out there you'd like shot?
We're going to fire 400 rounds tonight.
Just spray the area and hope some fool walking down the road with his bicycle and bag of rye steps into the incoming.
We had restrictions on where you could use this immense firepower.
Towns were off limits.
We prescribed a large set of circumstances.
I think they were noble in description.
However, the practical effect in the field was kill your own men.
Uh, before I left the advisory program, 1970, we had a directive, uh, directive number one, 1970, MACV1 or whatever it was, that said we could not fire on the enemy until fired upon, literally that.
If they're on one side of the road and you're on the other and they don't shoot at you, you let them come through.

my reply to that one will be yes sir we signed that gentleman and now let's go fight a war if you don't shoot them when you see them and i live over it i want to have a chat with you because it's just that's not at least my book how you do business but the army made that policy you you had the helicopters immense firepower do we use it we said we can't use it here we can't use it there you can't bring this to bear what we did
was we ran the army by political decisions.
And let's be fair, all armies answer to political leaders.
In our case, three layers of civilians, the president, the secretary of defense, the secretary of the army, and the other services.
So, lean back from the rock face.
That's the instruction that always creeps me out.
I would be...
I don't have to finish that.
But they always say, lean back from the rock face.
And I, uh-uh.
